text: So hello everyone. Thanks for coming to
my talk. Uh today I'm going to be
talking about Horde. Uh specifically how
it can be used by small teams. Um and
I'll show you ways we've reduced cost
and I'll show you what's actually
involved in deploying Horde.
Uh so before I get into things, just a
little bit about me and the company I
work for. Uh so my name is Ash. I'm a
lead real-time developer at S1T2. Uh
while my main focus is leading
development on our Unreal based
experiences, I'm also responsible for
maintaining and developing the DevOps
pipelines for these projects.
Uh so at S1T2, we mostly create
immersive and interactive experiences
typically for institutions like art
galleries and museums. uh and we use a
lot of different technologies but we
mainly use Unreal Engine for these
experiences.
Uh so at S1T2 uh we're a team that cares
about fast iteration. Uh that's kind of
due to the experimental nature of our
work as well as short timelines and the
need to adapt to changing requirements.
Uh our core team is also small um but we
may expand our team with contractors or
other partners depending on the work we
take on. And our team is also hybrid.
You know, some people work from the
office or work from home or maybe
on-site uh in another country. Uh so
having remote access to our tools and
infrastructure is important. Actually,
the picture in the bottom right is from
the time we did a job in Dubai and I got
stuck there for like 5 months.
Uh so this talk is targeted towards
small teams who are interested in Horde
but are unsure if it's the right thing
for them. uh as well as teams that don't
have continuous integration set up yet.
Uh to get the most out of this talk, it
would be best to have some knowledge of
Ford or similar tools. Uh but it's okay
if you don't. Actually, how many people
went to Jack's talk earlier on board?
Oh, not many.
Um so, is Epic's custom continuous
integration platform. Um it may even be
a bit reductive to call it just a
continuous integration platform. Um but
what sets it apart is its native support
for Unreal tools, projects and
workflows. Uh you know it offers uh
build graph support natively and
integrates with other Epic tools like
Unreal Games sync. Uh and it was also
designed with scale in mind. You know
it's got to accommodate the needs of a
team the size of Epic.
Uh so why would you choose Horde over
something else? Uh, Hord's out-of-box
experience is kind of unrivaled uh
specifically for Unreal Engine projects
just because of the um the native
integrations and streamlined process.
Uh it's also kind of an all-in-one
solution. Uh it comes with most things
you need out of the box which reduces
the need to create glue between
different tools or services.
Uh, and by choosing Horde, you're kind
of buying into the Unreal ecosystem of
tools, uh, and the Epic way of doing
things. Uh, which kind of reduces the
friction involved to introduce more Epic
tools into your workflow or pipeline.
Uh, and obviously scale. Uh, if you're a
global scale team, Hard does make a lot
of sense just because of its ability to
accommodate teams of that size.
Uh, so why wouldn't you choose Horde
then? Uh, Horde is pretty opinionated in
its workflows and integrations. So, if
you disagree with these or they don't
work for you, then it might not be the
right choice, and one of those
integrations is Perforce. Um, well, you
could find some way to integrate it or
migrate to Perforce. You might find that
it's more effort than it's worth. Um, or
maybe you're a studio that does a mix of
Unreal and non Unreal projects, or it's
going to make less sense for things that
aren't Unreal.
or perhaps you already have a system
that works. It can be hard to justify
moving away from something that's
already getting the job done.
Uh so I've broken up this talk into two
main sections. Uh first I'm going to
give an overview of requirements kind of
show you what the minimum is and then
we'll build a highle plan for our

going into more detail and show you ways

board configuration.

uh and or also has an issue system which

Uh so going through our options
uh an on-remise deployment can be
cheaper in the long term. uh we're able
to purchase hardware up front rather
than paying ongoing fees for cloud
hosting
but it can be harder to scale. It's not
like we can just spin up more servers at

also be less stable than a cloud
deployment. You know, we're more
susceptible to things like power or
internet outages as well as hardware
failure.
Uh so a cloud deployment can be more
expensive in the long term, but it's
going to offer greater flexibility and
the ability to scale on demand. Um, and
it may also offer more stability. Large
outages are uncommon. And when we're in
the cloud, hardware failure isn't really
a concern anymore.
And then hybrid can allow us to tap in
some of tap into some of the benefits of
both. Uh, as well as giving us the
flexibility to pivot.
Uh, so going with hybrid, it's not
really going to be the cheapest option,
uh, but can kind of give us the best of
both worlds. Uh by putting our critical

more confident in its stability. Uh and
by putting our agents on premises, we
can save some money by u buying hardware
up front or repurposing hardware that we
already own rather than paying ongoing
fees for high-spec cloud servers.

with EBS, we kind of have to allocate a

assuming there's no other bottlenecks.
Uh and it's generally going to be more

Uh so what about S3 then? Uh a nice

actually that now Horde can use
pre-signed URLs which essentially means

server.
Uh so here we're going to choose S3. Uh
it's nice that it is uh cheaper and

Uh so in terms of hardware, some things
are kind of obvious. Uh we want a CPU
with a lot of cores. With more cores, we
can do more in parallel. Uh and we also
want fast storage. Our agent's going to
be reading and writing a lot of files.
So an SSD is definitely recommended to
prevent that from becoming a bottleneck.
Uh a GPU is kind of optional. It really
depends on if you plan on running
automated tests on these agents and the
kinds of tests you're running. Uh and
then we're going to need enough RAM to
feed all of our cores. Uh, but how would
you know how much RAM is enough?
Uh, if you've ever compiled an Unreal
Engine project before, you've probably
seen a message like this. Uh, here it's
saying it's limited to one uh, process
per logical core. In this case, it's 20.
Uh, and then it's requesting 1.5 GB of
memory per process, and there's only
currently 25 GB available. Uh, so it's
being limited to 16 processes out of the
maximum of 20.
Uh what this means is the agent doesn't
have enough available RAM to saturate
all of the cores. So it's not really
going to be enough to just like throw
more cores at your agent. Um I would
generally recommend budgeting about 2 GB
of RAM per thread. Uh which will give
plenty of buffer, but what you really
want is that 1.5 GB per thread plus a
bit of buffer.
Uh this limiter is artificial and it can
be turned off. Uh it might help in
situations where the agent doesn't have
enough RAM. Uh but it's generally better
just to make sure they have enough in
the first place. Uh we do disable this
limiter on our build agents just in case
there's like a spike in memory usage and
we want to make sure they're always
using the maximum amount of parallel

cause boolean. Uh it's kind of set true

Uh so we want to set this to true.

Hord has two main requirements for CI.
Uh the first is that we must have Unreal
Engine source code on Perforce. Um, so
even if you don't plan on modifying it,
we're going to need to put some thought
into how we structure our perfor streams
to ingest the engine source code. Uh,
and the second is that our projects must
be considered native, which is
essentially a folder structure that we
must follow.
Uh, so starting with streams, uh, we
want to create at least two streams. Uh,
the first being an entry point. This
will just contain like the stock Unreal
Engine with no modifications. Uh, and
then we'll create another stream where
we can actually develop changes in.
uh but I would also recommend creating a
third stream as a buffer between the
two. Uh and this will give us a place to
uh merge incoming changes with our own
modifications.
Uh so that might look something like

which is our entry point. Uh then at the

for merging.
Uh the way we set up our streams, it
kind of follows a similar structure. Uh
here UI main is our entry point. Um and
then below that, UB dev mostly acts as a
buffer, but we do develop some changes
there. Uh and then we branch off UB dev
to create a stream for each project.
Uh we also have these release streams.
Uh they're kind of snapshots of the
engine as we've ingested them and
they're mostly there for compiling

Uh the next thing we need is for our
projects to be considered native. Uh and
we have to meet one of two criteria. Uh
the first is that our project folder
must be relative to the engine
directory. And the second is if it's in
a subdirectory, that subdirectory needs
to be listed by a project as file. Uh to
achieve this, we could just push our

uh and that's using stream components.
Uh what this allows us to do is
essentially create a separate stream for
our project. Uh and then we can map the
contents of that stream to any workspace
created for our engine. Uh so if you
sync your engine stream, you'll also get
your project in a subdirectory.
Uh so why would you even bother doing it
this way? Uh using stream components
kind of decouples your engine and
project streams, meaning they can be mix
and matched or merged and branched in
isolation. Uh another nice benefit is
that it can be applied retroactively or
even undone without having to push files
around different streams. So it kind of
offers greater flexibility overall.

and this can lead to improvements in

Uh so OIDC stands for open ID connect.
It's kind of a standard that provides
two main purposes. Uh the first is login
flow. Uh so that will allow users to log
into your service potentially with
accounts they created on other platforms
like Google or GitHub. Uh and then the
second is user identity. Um when once
logged in your service will receive
information about the user like their
name or their email address.
Uh so Horde has two main login flows
that we need to understand. Uh the first
is signing into the dashboard. Uh so if
you browse to your Horde server, it's
basically basically going to immediately
redirect you to your provider's login
page. Uh there you would fill out your
details and sign in. Um and you'll be
redirected back to the dashboard in a
signed state.
Uh and the second login flow is with
desktop tools like Unreal Games sync. So
when Unreal Games Sync wants to
authenticate uh it first host a local
HTTP server with a web page uh and then
it will open your browser uh to your
provider's login page. There you will
login as normal. Um and this time you'll
be redirected to that locally hosted web
page. Uh Unreal Games Sync will see that
it's been redirected to and then store
the information it received in a file to
be used later.
Uh the second thing we're going to get
from our provider is user identity. Um
so when a user signs into Horde, it's
going to receive a list of claims that
describe a user. Uh claims are just key
values. They can be things like their
email address, their name, profile
picture. And in Horde, we're also able
to assign permissions to these claims.
Uh so if a user's email claim is
asht2.com,
uh then they can have the execute or
permission. for example.
